DOC.HEAD: FBI Arrests Six in Attempted Bank Robbery
DOC.TEXT: The FBI and state and local police arrested six men Saturday who had broken into a bank and are potential suspects in bank burglaries in the United States and Canada, an FBI spokesman said. The men had already outsmarted the bank's alarm system when they were arrested about 4 a.m. while trying to break into the vault of the Coolidge Bank and Trust Co., said spokesman Paul Cavanaugh. The arrests culminated a 14- to 16-month joint investigation and surveillance involving the FBI and Montreal police, Cavanaugh said. The men had broken in by drilling a hole through a concrete floor from offices above the bank. They were carrying a cache of burglary tools, electronic scanners and walkie-talkies, FBI officials said. Arrested were James Joseph McCormack, 50, and John Joseph Murray, 35, both of Charlestown; Benjamin Wonsch, 49, of Plymouth; and Paul T. Bryntwick, 38, Ronald McCann, 57, and Talbot Murphy, 61, all of Montreal. The men were being held in area jails, and were scheduled to be arraigned Tuesday in U.S. District Court in Boston. The six are possible suspects in a half-dozen unsolved bank burglaries in the United States and Canada, Cavanaugh said. Saturday's heist was similar to a successful 1988 holiday weekend burglary of a Boston bank that reportedly netted $125,000.
